","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZBUS1101","attributes":[{"name":"Introductory Course","code":"introductory_course","description":"This course is usually taken in the early part of a program and may be required as a pre-requisite before taking a more advanced course."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS1101 - Organisational Behaviour","description":"

Organisations are a permanent aspect of our current social system. We have structured our existence around groups of people organised together to achieve particular outcomes. How and why these groups achieve goals (or fail trying) is an enduring question within the social sciences. This course will introduce you to a range of explanations for how organisations function. I will take a three tiered approach to the problem of organisational behaviour by looking at social/cultural determinants, small group interaction and individual behaviour. This approach will necessarily be cross-disciplinary and challenging to our preconceived notions of how the world works and why.

Free Passion Feedback 1: this will describe an aspect of behaviour the students are looking at and the preliminary research they would have done on the topic of their choice.

\n

Free Passion Feedback 2: Students have to state what they will be arguing and explain the theoretical/conceptual side of it.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"44421d33dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7f321d33dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"80421d33dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"88421d33dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3b321d33dbf91c50eb6b147a3a961909","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Free Passion Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

Students are allowed to pick an aspect of behaviour that they are passionate about and explain it in an interesting way. This assignment will be between 2000 and 2500 words in length.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"44421d33dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96195b","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7f321d33dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"80421d33dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96195e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"88421d33dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96193f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"73321d33dbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Tutorial Participation","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

The tutorial participation mark is based upon the students' performance in tutorials. Tutors will be looking for intelligent contributions to the discussion and clear indications that they have read, and thought about the tutorial reading/topic.

contentlets.description: Organisations are a permanent aspect of our current social system. We have structured our existence around groups of people organised together to achieve particular outcomes. How and why these groups achieve goals (or fail trying) is an enduring question within the social sciences. This course will introduce you to a range of explanations for how organisations function. I will take a three tiered approach to the problem of organisational behaviour by looking at social/cultural determinants, small group interaction and individual behaviour. This approach will necessarily be cross-disciplinary and challenging to our preconceived notions of how the world works and why.

The course introduces you to the main principles of economics. It briefly reviews the development of ideas in the discipline and provides the foundation to understanding the economic environment in which organisations conduct business. Students will learn how economists model behaviour of individuals and firms. They will also learn how policies are used by governments to influence outcomes in the market place.

contentlets.description: The course introduces you to the main principles of economics. It briefly reviews the development of ideas in the discipline and provides the foundation to understanding the economic environment in which organisations conduct business. Students will learn how economists model behaviour of individuals and firms. They will also learn how policies are used by governments to influence outcomes in the market place.
contentlets.title: Business Economics

This course aims to provide business students with an understanding of how accounting information is used for decision making and to create information on the financial performance of an organisation. To do this, you will need to understand how accounting information is created, presented and interpreted. This course provides an introduction to financial management across the School of Business undergraduate program, and, in particular, the Financial Management course.

This course is the first of three, comprising the Integrating Core in the BBus degree. The Integrating Core courses aim to systematically develop the critical thinking, research and problem solving skills that are required for success in business environments.  This course presents management as a profession that is founded on research.  It outlines the broad range of activities that constitute management and shows how different management activities can be supported by different types of research.  It aims to develop managers who use research evidence to support decision making and policy making.  In this course, students learn how to locate and critically analyse information in the management research literature. The course has a particular focus on developing Graduate Attributes and intellectual skills which may be applied to enhance understanding and performance in other courses in the degree.

contentlets.description: This course is the first of three, comprising the Integrating Core in the BBus degree. The Integrating Core courses aim to systematically develop the critical thinking, research and problem solving skills that are required for success in business environments.  This course presents management as a profession that is founded on research.  It outlines the broad range of activities that constitute management and shows how different management activities can be supported by different types of research.  It aims to develop managers who use research evidence to support decision making and policy making.  In this course, students learn how to locate and critically analyse information in the management research literature. The course has a particular focus on developing Graduate Attributes and intellectual skills which may be applied to enhance understanding and performance in other courses in the degree.
contentlets.title: Foundations of Management

This course aims to provide a general understanding of the law and legal processes operating within a private or public business context. The course introduces students to a range of legal topics and issues underpinning the conduct of commercial enterprises and making of business decisions. There is particular emphasis on contract law as a key knowledge tool for working effectively in the procurement processes of large organisations (such as the Defence Department). Legal analysis, writing and problem solving skills are developed throughout the course.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZBUS2206","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS2206 - Managing People Across Cultures","description":"

Managing People Across Cultures is an elective in the management stream of the Bachelor of Business. The course introduces students to the knowledge and approaches they will need to manage across borders and cultures. The course provides conceptual and theoretical frameworks for understanding cultural differences, as well as the dynamics and challenges of cross-cultural communication in multicultural work teams and organisations, at home and internationally.

contentlets.description: Managing People Across Cultures is an elective in the management stream of the Bachelor of Business. The course introduces students to the knowledge and approaches they will need to manage across borders and cultures. The course provides conceptual and theoretical frameworks for understanding cultural differences, as well as the dynamics and challenges of cross-cultural communication in multicultural work teams and organisations, at home and internationally.

Organisations are continually striving to develop their innovation capabilities, skills and culture. This 6UOC course aims to equip students with an awareness of the role, impact and challenges of innovation within an organisation, so as to reduce risk and increase effectiveness.  The importance of innovation for all aspects of organisational effectiveness, not just new products or services, will be stressed. This will support students as they develop strategies across a broad range of topics and disciplines.


This course will examine definitions of innovation, the importance of innovation in creating competitive advantage, how organisational leaders can support innovation and an innovation culture.

contentlets.description:
Organisations are continually striving to develop their innovation capabilities, skills and culture. This 6UOC course aims to equip students with an awareness of the role, impact and challenges of innovation within an organisation, so as to reduce risk and increase effectiveness.  The importance of innovation for all aspects of organisational effectiveness, not just new products or services, will be stressed. This will support students as they develop strategies across a broad range of topics and disciplines.

This course will examine definitions of innovation, the importance of innovation in creating competitive advantage, how organisational leaders can support innovation and an innovation culture.
contentlets.title: Innovation and Organisation

This course considers leadership as a management activity and includes critical analysis of the assumptions underlying leadership. Students will link their leadership experiences to leadership theory. In this course you will consider what leadership is and why it is needed as well as approaches to leadership, leadership skills (interpersonal skills, self-management, emotional intelligence) leadership theories, the individual as a leader, personal leadership, power and authority, developing vision, followership, motivation and ethical leadership. You will explore and develop a personal model of leadership and the responsibilities and accountabilities of being a leader, and leadership development and training.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS2304 - Management Accounting","description":"

This course develops an understanding of management accounting with a view to equip students with the ability to address costing and budgeting issues in a complex organisational environment. Acquisition of the tools of management accounting is presented as a means of assisting in the effective and efficient control of organisational resources. Management accounting is compared and contrasted with financial accounting; a range of conceptual and measurement issues around costing is explored; various approaches to budgeting are considered; the impact of human factors is addressed; and methods of managing quantities (for example in inventories) are presented.

This course deals with investment evaluation and finance. Standard investment appraisal techniques are introduced, and a range of issues in financial analysis are covered. Topics covered may include evaluation under conditions of risk and uncertainty for public and private enterprises. Financial topics covered include standard techniques such as discounted cash flow, financial statement analysis, capital asset pricing, security evaluation, optimal capital structure, and sources of capital from financial institutions in Australia.

This course introduces students to key theories and concepts of business and business activities in a regional and international context. Throughout the course, students will have the opportunity to critically examine the opportunities and challenges that arise from conducting business in different political, economic and cultural settings. Some of the topics covered in the course will include globalisation, International Trade and Payments, geographical, cultural and institutional factors, regional blocs and markets, international dimensions of marketing and strategic management.

contentlets.description:
Students will undertake a research project commensurate with Year 2 study, supported by a supervisor. Bachelor of Business CDF students will complete this course in Semester 1 of Year 2, in lieu of a Level 2 business elective.  

In this course, students will select their research topic and develop a research question or hypothesis. Students will also undertake a literature review and commence drafting a thesis.

contentlets.description:
Students will continue a research project commensurate with Year 2 study, supported by a supervisor. Bachelor of Business CDF students will complete this course in Semester 2 of Year 2, in lieu of a Level 2 business elective.  

In this course, students will choose a research methodology and appropriate methods relevant to their research project, and draft the methodology chapter of their thesis. 

Students may be required to seek ethics approval at this stage of the research project.
contentlets.title: Research Project in Business 1

This course aims to broaden the understanding of the law and legal processes operating within a private or public business context. The course introduces students to a range of legal topics and issues underpinning the successful management of a commercial enterprise and the making of business decisions (ranging from environmental law to cyber law). Students should have undertaken Business Law ZBUS2101 as a prerequisite to this course.

This capstone course uses disciplinary concepts and analytical techniques from BBus core courses to solve complex organisational problems. It draws on case studies from the public, private, non-profit, and international sectors to workshop evidence-based approaches to overcoming performance and leadership challenges. It builds on skills of problem definition, analysis, and decision making by showing how solutions may be implemented in business and organisational settings. It applies organisation theory and social network analysis to diagnose the strengths and weaknesses of organisations and informal networks. Study in this course also draws on theories of leadership, negotiation, organisational change, structure, culture, economics and politics. It considers the formulation of business strategy and its implementation in an environment of continuous change.

Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"ZBUS3106","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS3106 - Business and Sustainable Development","description":"

This course introduces students to the principles of sustainable development and how they apply to business. It is a critical component of modern business practice with implications for the environment, society (current and future generations) and the economy. The course begins by taking students on a ‘walk-through’ the evolution of the concept of sustainable development, exploring its inherent paradoxes, and the subsequent rise of alternative development paradigms (e.g. Gross National Happiness, Human Development Index, OECD Better Life Index). Students will gain an understanding into how businesses can meet their environmental, social and economic responsibilities through the framework of sustainable development. Students will develop knowledge and skills that will allow them to undertake a critical analysis of the setting and measuring of development targets and thus the capacity for sustainable development in the ‘real world’.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"e3140dfbdb391c50eb6b147a3a96191e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Consultancy Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"40","description":"

Students will prepare a consultant’s report on the basis of a hypothetical case study. The student’s report will be 1,500 words and will include sections that relate to sustainable development (SD):

·         Company overview and rationale for commitment to SD

·         Organisation’s SD targets for (year)

·         Environmental performance

·         Social performance

·         Economic performance

·         Summary and future targets

Students are required to read articles provided in the first few weeks of semester on the paradoxes of ‘sustainable development and business’. They must prepare a presentation describing:

·         What paradoxes of sustainable development can be observed?

·         How do the paradoxes affect sustainable development in practice?

·         How, if at all, could businesses achieve sustainable development?

Presentations will be 10 minutes long and given during an allocated tutorial time slot. Individuals will be assessed on:

·         The clarity of the presentation

·         The critical reflection on the concept

The completeness of the content

Illicit business is an important area of study because it affects all levels of society. It distorts international trade, threatens the health and safety of consumers, and creates significant problems for regulatory and law enforcement agencies. Money laundering, tax havens, counterfeiting, conflict diamonds, terrorist financing, drug trafficking, arms smuggling,  trafficking of wildlife, human body parts, and ancient historical artefacts, as well as human smuggling and the modern-day slave trade constitute billion dollar global industries that form an increasingly important part of the global economy.  These illicit businesses and dark economies facilitate terrorism, war and conflict, corruption and present serious challenges to the national security of states across the world. This course introduces students to the dark side of international business in order to develop approaches to addressing the challenges they pose.

contentlets.keywords: business,illicit business,black economy,international business,corruption,national security,dark economies
contentlets.description: Illicit business is an important area of study because it affects all levels of society. It distorts international trade, threatens the health and safety of consumers, and creates significant problems for regulatory and law enforcement agencies. Money laundering, tax havens, counterfeiting, conflict diamonds, terrorist financing, drug trafficking, arms smuggling,  trafficking of wildlife, human body parts, and ancient historical artefacts, as well as human smuggling and the modern-day slave trade constitute billion dollar global industries that form an increasingly important part of the global economy.  These illicit businesses and dark economies facilitate terrorism, war and conflict, corruption and present serious challenges to the national security of states across the world. This course introduces students to the dark side of international business in order to develop approaches to addressing the challenges they pose.
contentlets.title: Illicit Business in the Modern World

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS3203 - The Making of Economic Policy","description":"

This course deals with the process of economic policy making and analyses the rationale for, and implications of, economic policies in open economies.


Topics covered may include rationale for government activity and intervention; critiques of the size and economic role of government; public versus private ownership; production and provision; regulation and deregulation; competition and industry policy; implications of economic policy for economic welfare, and for security, defence and defence industry.

This course focuses on the role of the state in developing countries. It traces the emergence of the Third World and the concepts of development, development management and governance before examining the contemporary environment in which development takes place. Items include the pressing problems of weak states, widespread issues of law and order, and the challenges of rebuilding post-conflict states. The course provides an understanding of public sector management in developing countries as well as specific issues including decentralisation, planning, foreign aid and relations with civil society. Students will be equipped with the knowledge and skills to analyse and understand the context, practices and possibilities for development in different types of developing countries. The course uses a problem-oriented approach seeking practical solutions to pressing problems of development.

This course introduces a suite of marketing-related ideas. It begins by presenting a series of concepts and techniques that will help students identify and analyze elements of the organization's operating environment, including its stakeholders. It then develops a strategic approach to stakeholder engagement, particularly through targeting certain groups with specific offerings. Lastly, the course presents an approach to implementing marketing through communications approaches, product/ service development, pricing market offerings and distributing market offerings. In summary, the course offers a broader view of marketing than tradition 'sales' and 'advertising'.

This course gives an introduction to theories and practices of logistics and supply chain management, with an emphasis on learning and addressing the challenges associated with the movement of people, goods and services. The focus of the course will be on the process of logistics activities such as procurement, transportation, inventory management, Just-in-time strategy, warehousing, materials handling, information management and sharing and risk modelling, identification and quantification. In addition, the course will cover the latest trends, opportunities and challenges faced by logistics providers from the commercial and military perspectives because of globalisation. During the course, students will be required to apply their learning in the Australian Defence Force context to address problems in that domain.

Students will continue a research project that they commenced in Semester 1 of Year 2. Students will continue to work with their chosen supervisor. Bachelor of Business CDF students will complete this course in Semester 1 of Year 3, in lieu of a Level 3 business elective.  

In this course, students will undertake data collection and analysis, and draft appropriate thesis chapter(s).

Students will continue a research project that they commenced in Semester 1 of Year 2. Students will continue to work with their chosen supervisor. Bachelor of Business CDF students will complete this course in Semester 2 of Year 3, in lieu of a Level 3 business elective. 

In this course, students will synthesise research undertaken in ZBUS2901, ZBUS2902 and ZBUS3901. Students will draft remaining sections of the thesis, and finalise the fully drafted thesis prior to submission.

The objective of this course is to investigate the role of strategy in achieving organisational success in commercial environments. It examines the nature of organisational objectives, capabilities and strategies and, in particular, the role of corporate and business strategies as determinants of superior performance. This course also addresses corporate social responsibility in strategic management.

contentlets.description: The objective of this course is to investigate the role of strategy in achieving organisational success in commercial environments. It examines the nature of organisational objectives, capabilities and strategies and, in particular, the role of corporate and business strategies as determinants of superior performance. This course also addresses corporate social responsibility in strategic management.

This course analyses the behaviour of individuals and groups within organisational structures and the interactions that occur between the individual, the group and the organisation. Students will analyse the relationships between patterns of human behaviour and management concepts and practices, and will develop the conceptual framework required to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of those practices.

This course introduces investment decision making solution techniques. It focuses on corporate finance from an investor's perspective. It also provides an explanation of financing options, including how financial markets operate and the main instruments of financial markets. The course is very hands-on, and makes extensive use of examples. The structure of the course is sequential and each module builds on the techniques and concepts of previous modules. The course is delivered through material apportioned on a week-by-week basis available online via Moodle. Those with no or limited experience of financial concepts should consider undertaking ZBUS8149 as introduction to this. The suggested textbook is recommended. The style is guide-by-the-side rather than sage-on-the-stage, so you are expected to study independently and participate actively and regularly to the online forum.

This course provides an introduction to accounting information, terminology and techniques. This applied course is designed to give students confidence in using financial information in the workplace. It covers the identification of accounting information, the preparation and analysis of financial accounting reports - including company financial statements, and a practical understanding of the key management accounting techniques used to inform business decisions.

Business Law aims to provide an introduction to, and general understanding of, the law in key legal areas applying within a private or public business context. Topics covered in the course include: the Australian legal system, contract law, torts law, competition and consumer law, sale of goods legislation, business entities, intellectual property law and agency law and ethics. The purpose of the course is to equip students with sufficient knowledge of the legal system and law to understand the legal implications of business actions. Legal analysis and problem-solving skills are developed throughout the course. The course is intended for managers who are not lawyers and no prior knowledge of law is required.

This is an applied course covering two of a project's four global phases: planning and execution. The objective of the course is to equip students with the knowledge and skills to play a leadership role over these parts of a project's life. Research suggests that a large proportion of projects fail because of inadequate planning and management. The course explores methods, tools and techniques to support the effective management of projects (regardless of setting). This is a "companion" to ZBUS8147: The Business of Managing projects. While neither is a pre-requisite for the other, participants are assumed to have had some exposure to projects (commercial, social, government or defence).

It is widely accepted that developing good policy is only one part of delivering effective outcomes; effective implementation is also critical. In this course students are introduced to an implementation cycle, which stresses an end user focus, and the elements provide the basis for the curriculum. Topics will include: the impact of internal and external context; ways of engaging with stakeholders; success identification; system level change; capability identification and development; risk assessment and mitigation; performance and accountability management; measurement review and evaluation; enacting implementation; and continuous review. The aim is to prepare students for the messy reality of implementation through introducing both the range of issues involved, and the inevitable complexity of the interactions of different public service stakeholders and organisations.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS8114 - Leadership of Safe and Healthy Work","description":"

This course reconceptualises obligations for ensuring the health and safety of workers by helping students shift their attention from ‘work health and safety’ to ‘safe and healthy work’.  Case studies will help students explore how WHS theories, principles and performance measures can be integrated into the processes and information systems that support strategic and operational decision-making by business leaders. Topics will include understanding the due diligence obligations of business leaders; recognising WHS risk within complex organisational systems; defining and evaluating WHS performance; supporting effective decision-making; and assurance and verification of safe and healthy work. The course aims to develop capability for recognising and delivering solutions that achieve dual financial and non-financial objectives.

The Business of Managing Projects (BoMP) provides the skills and knowledge for students to understand the business, organisational, cultural and social, or human, aspects of project management.


This course considers the central role of projects in business, organisational strategy, and decision-making. Key questions include how projects impact on business and organisational objectives, the effect of organisational decisions on project success or failure, the importance of leadership and management skills, the role of the project manager in managing stakeholder expectations and delivering project outcomes.

contentlets.description:
The Business of Managing Projects (BoMP) provides the skills and knowledge for students to understand the business, organisational, cultural and social, or human, aspects of project management.

This course considers the central role of projects in business, organisational strategy, and decision-making. Key questions include how projects impact on business and organisational objectives, the effect of organisational decisions on project success or failure, the importance of leadership and management skills, the role of the project manager in managing stakeholder expectations and delivering project outcomes.
contentlets.title: The Business of Managing Projects

This course covers the basics of Finance including the time value of money, risk aversion, nominal and real amounts, arbitrage, simple and compounded interest, annuities, valuing shares and debt, and net present value. The course is highly applied, using everyday examples and relying on continuous problem solving to ensure progress and assessment. Specific objectives include: covering fundamental concepts used to make financial decisions; covering key methods used in the valuation of assets; providing knowledge to better understand financial topics and decisions as reported in the media and public policy; preparing students to take more advanced courses in finance such as ZBUS8105 Finance and Investment Appraisal.


Examples of topics covered include cash flows, rates of return, and discount rates for valuing projects and assets as well as an overview of Australia's capital markets.

contentlets.description:
This course covers the basics of Finance including the time value of money, risk aversion, nominal and real amounts, arbitrage, simple and compounded interest, annuities, valuing shares and debt, and net present value. The course is highly applied, using everyday examples and relying on continuous problem solving to ensure progress and assessment. Specific objectives include: covering fundamental concepts used to make financial decisions; covering key methods used in the valuation of assets; providing knowledge to better understand financial topics and decisions as reported in the media and public policy; preparing students to take more advanced courses in finance such as ZBUS8105 Finance and Investment Appraisal.

Examples of topics covered include cash flows, rates of return, and discount rates for valuing projects and assets as well as an overview of Australia's capital markets.

contentlets.description: This course develops an understanding of leadership as a holistic process that involves influencing people both inside and outside the organisation. The dynamics of interpersonal influence processes are investigated, with particular attention given to the broader conceptualisation of leadership style, such as 'transformational' and 'transactional' leadership.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZBUS8203","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS8203 - Change Management","description":"

The course introduces students to a broad range of current change literature including the problems and key issues relating to managing change in organisations. Key topics include metaphors for understanding change, theories of planned change, the role of the change agent, diagnosis, responses to change, the process of planned change, interventions (techno-structural, strategic, cross-cultural), managing and leading change, current issues and challenges.

contentlets.description: The course offers a comprehensive survey of the vocabulary, concepts, and techniques of marketing. The course develops a systematic approach for examining the successful delivery of product, place, promotion, pricing, positioning, and service, with the end goals of creating product value and customer satisfaction. The course aims to integrate marketing analysis and research plans, information on consumer behaviour, target segments, strategy development, brand management, global marketing, and social responsibility. The course is designed for managers in both profit and non-profit organisations and examines marketing across a variety of industries and institutions.
contentlets.title: Marketing

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZBUS8205","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS8205 - Business Ethics","description":"

Business enterprises in the modern global economy are routinely faced with challenging ethical issues. Do corporations have "social responsibilities" beyond making profit for their shareholders? Is it morally acceptable to use bribery in cultures where it is normal and widely practised? Is the use of sweatshop labour exploitative? Is networking for career advantage a form of "cheating"? What counts as "discrimination" in the workplace? Must the most qualified candidate always be appointed? Is advertising to children and other vulnerable groups appropriate? What's so bad about 'insider trading'? This course will equip students with the analytical tools to anticipate, critically assess, and appropriately respond to the ethical challenges that arise in business and professional life, both in the private and the public sector.

The basic supply chain management and logistical concepts will be studied within the context of the humanitarian and disaster relief environment. Various civilian and military applications are considered in a global context. All phases of the Disaster Management Cycle (DMC) will be covered. Different logistical strategies needs and techniques are required for each phase.


The aim of the course is to provide a solid theoretical base for logisticians working within the humanitarian environment. At the end of this course students will understand the different phases of the DMC and will be aware of the different logistical needs, flows and performance indicators associated with each phase. As this is a relatively new course emphasis is given to future avenues opening in humanitarian logistics such as professional collaborations, civil-military co-ordination and challenges.

contentlets.description:
The basic supply chain management and logistical concepts will be studied within the context of the humanitarian and disaster relief environment. Various civilian and military applications are considered in a global context. All phases of the Disaster Management Cycle (DMC) will be covered. Different logistical strategies needs and techniques are required for each phase.

The aim of the course is to provide a solid theoretical base for logisticians working within the humanitarian environment. At the end of this course students will understand the different phases of the DMC and will be aware of the different logistical needs, flows and performance indicators associated with each phase. As this is a relatively new course emphasis is given to future avenues opening in humanitarian logistics such as professional collaborations, civil-military co-ordination and challenges.
contentlets.title: Humanitarian Logistics

Critical Analysis in Business is designed to deepen students' understanding of discipline and field-specific epistemological approaches and literary practices.  It develops student capacity to engage with knowledge from the business domain at a deeper level through examination of evidence and argument.  This is achieved through opportunities to develop the research and critical review skills required to complete academic tasks (e.g. empirical research, reports, review essays or case studies) integral to advanced business knowledge. Students practice developing different types of argument through an iterative writing process, from problem conceptualisation through to the final argument.  Graduates of this course have an advanced understanding of critical thinking as it applies to problems of concept and practice in business.The course provides students with business writing skills that will enable them to complete academic tasks for courses within the Master of Business.

The aim of this course is to give you an insight into Logistics and Global Supply Chain Management. Many students come to this subject with their own (mis)interpretations of what is meant by logistics and supply chain management. By the end of the module, you should be clear what is meant by these terms and how they differ from each other. While the discussion on the linguistic origins of logistics might appear superficial, it is nonetheless important as it highlights the military roots of logistics.

This course is tailored to meet the requirements of the Capability and Technology Management College (CTMC). The course aims to examine the concepts and techniques required to sustain the physical asset elements of a capability. The course will provide students with various case studies to examine world’s best practice as well as physical asset management sustainment failures. These cases include civilian and military applications. The course covers the various aspects of physical asset sustainment, in particular: maintenance and inventory requirements, fundamental inputs to capability (FIC) requirements, the establishment and operation of supply chains and configuration management systems required and the use of life cycle costing (LCC) to support a physical asset fleet throughout its life cycle. Through a series of lecture presentations, discussions and workshops, students will develop an understanding of physical asset sustainment.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS8308 - Business Planning","description":"

This course addresses key aspects of planning and managing a business. and includes business case analysis, writing a business proposal and communicating business outcomes to different audiences. This course also examines the evaluation of business information, selecting appropriate sources and targeting your audience.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZBUS8310","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS8310 - Commercial Skills in the Public Sector","description":"

As a result of far-reaching economic and social trends, the Australian Defence Force relies on commercial contractors, not only for the supply of platforms and systems but also for the repair, maintenance and adaptation of those platforms and systems in-service. Effective management of the business relationship between defence customer and commercial supplier across the full materiel life cycle is therefore a key input to defence capability. The Commercial Skills in the Public Sector course is intended to help defence managers develop the commercial acumen required to manage defence business relationships with an eye to their wider defence capability significance. To this end the course will address the interface between Defence-specific requirements and the wider principles of financial management, legal practice, contracting, procurement and the management of supplier relationships.

contentlets.keywords: business,contract law,contract management,incomplete contracting,principal agent problems,financial statement analysis,budgeting,costing,risk and financial management,supplier management,defence procurement
contentlets.description: As a result of far-reaching economic and social trends, the Australian Defence Force relies on commercial contractors, not only for the supply of platforms and systems but also for the repair, maintenance and adaptation of those platforms and systems in-service. Effective management of the business relationship between defence customer and commercial supplier across the full materiel life cycle is therefore a key input to defence capability. The Commercial Skills in the Public Sector course is intended to help defence managers develop the commercial acumen required to manage defence business relationships with an eye to their wider defence capability significance. To this end the course will address the interface between Defence-specific requirements and the wider principles of financial management, legal practice, contracting, procurement and the management of supplier relationships.
contentlets.title: Commercial Skills in the Public Sector

contentlets.keywords: business,contract law,contract management,incomplete contracting,principal agent problems,financial statement analysis,budgeting,costing
contentlets.description: This course introduces some of the best practical methods and tools for creating business value using big data. It goes above algorithms or logistics into building data literacy, reasoning and analytics capability. This course focuses on your business questions, helping you identify which data could answer these questions, where the data is, how to find the right data from heterogeneous sources, and how to bring the data together, followed by addressing the right analytics models and how to apply them to deliver the right insight for the right stakeholders or decision makers. This course uses simply explanations to illustrate complex concepts such as data science, AI and Blockchain. It focuses on using open source tools to reason what has happened, why it happened, what is the best that could happen, and how you can make it happen.
contentlets.title: Logistics Intelligence and Big Data Analysis

The aim of this course is to give you the knowledge on risk management and control in global logistics operations. It will explain the methods, tools and techniques on how to identify areas of losses, minimise and mitigate any financial, asset and human lives losses and help prepare the next generation of entrepreneurs or industry leaders for the changing business environments. The course introduces students to both academic research and industry practice. Due to the nature of global operations, and cooperation of multi-players, multi-operations and multi-systems, the course examines how risks are identified and projected from uncertainties, how it is assessed and what are some of the various different ways to manage the potential risks. It will also give an explanation of the practical, theoretical tools and methodologies which are currently used in Risk Management of business operations. Through assignments, the expectations from you is by taking the learned knowledge think on how the some of the current logistics operations be performed in a more efficient manner.

The People and Systems course considers the role of people in delivering organizational effectiveness and high performance, in conjunction with the impact of their managers on the outcomes. The concept of systems thinking and the role of people as part of those systems will be introduced. The course then considers the role of people and reflects on the way people will behave within the systems. The key course outcome is to ensure that managers recognise their role in enabling and supporting others to achieve their goals, and the consequences of not doing this well. The course will take students through a number of real world case studies and present the challenges faced by managers when first taking responsibility for a team of people within an organisation.

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZBUS8315","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS8315 - Driving Performance","description":"

This course equips managers with the knowledge and understanding of theory, concepts and approaches related to the utilisation of reward and performance management routines so as to maximise organisational outcomes. If change in a business strategy is to be implemented successfully, it must be underpinned by performance management and reward strategies that are aligned to the new aims of the organisation. This course integrates different aspects of managing people, including rewards, incentives and performance management in ways that will support change and the creation of high performing individuals.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"19b8dd4bdb835450358b403c3a9619a8","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

 

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e1b8dd4bdb835450358b403c3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e1b8dd4bdb835450358b403c3a9619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"65b8118bdb835450358b403c3a961936","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Work based Issue - Overview and summary","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Students will identify a performance related issue within their workplace (e.g. a need to achieve High Performance, poor team integration, weaknesses in reward or performance management systems or processes) and write an overview of the issue and what theory might help them to address the problem and why. 

Students will be issued with a marking rubric for the reflective portfolio entry at the outset of the course. They will submit their assessment and a self-assessment into Moodle. The assessment will be marked using the rubric and then returned to them with the completed rubric and comments.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e1b8dd4bdb835450358b403c3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e1b8dd4bdb835450358b403c3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"e5b8dd4bdb835450358b403c3a9619aa","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6db8118bdb835450358b403c3a96193b","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Integrating Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

Students will choose one aspect of reward management and one aspect of performance management. The relationships between the theories will be explored and the implications for driving performance in terms of both outcomes and behaviours outlined will be explored. 

Students will be issued with a marking rubric for the reflective portfolio entry at the outset of the course. They will submit their assessment and a self-assessment into Moodle. The assessment will be marked using the rubric and then returned to them with the completed rubric and comments.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"e1b8dd4bdb835450358b403c3a9619ab","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"e1b8dd4bdb835450358b403c3a9619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"e9b8dd4bdb835450358b403c3a9619ab","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b5b8118bdb835450358b403c3a961940","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Work based Issue - Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

Based on the overview in Assessment 1, students will prepare a report using the theory discussed to develop recommendations for change. The report will include recommendations for improving reward and performance management practices, a discussion of how required employee behaviours will align with these revised practices, but also an overview of potential implementation issues to be managed.

Students will be issued with a marking rubric for the reflective portfolio entry at the outset of the course. They will submit their assessment and a self-assessment into Moodle. The assessment will be marked using the rubric and then returned to them with the completed rubric and comments.

contentlets.keywords: business,resource based view,human capital,social capital,intellectual capital,management development,learning and development,capacity building,organisational capability,individual capability
contentlets.description: This course integrates different aspects of human capital, social capital, intellectual capital and human resources systems in order to determine how to develop long term organizational capability capable of supporting both adaptability and innovation.  The importance of organizational alignment and fit in order to enable the systems to be adaptable will be discussed.  The subject includes learning theory, training needs analysis; training design, assessment and evaluation; the role of the manager as coach and the outsourcing of training provision to external providers. In addition, it explores approaches to management development and succession planning and techniques for measuring return on training investment. The integrated nature of all aspects of people based interventions will be assessed and the need for all implementation plans to be developed in a holistic way.
contentlets.title: Developing Organisational Capability

A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"UNSW Canberra","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"ZBUS8317","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"ZBUS8317 - Workforce Planning","description":"

Workforce planning directly impacts organisational productivity and outcome through the process of systematically forecasting the future demand and supply of the employees and how to best deploy their skills in order to support the strategic development of the organisation. The course, which is designed for middle managers, includes: the context for workforce planning, how it is used as a strategic tool, the principles of workforce supply and demand, how to integrate capacity building and skills into workforce planning and the impact of workforce planning on other system elements such as diversity and flexibility.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"66efd432db83d850eb6b147a3a961954","name":"Fully online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Strategic Briefing","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

In this assessment students are given the scenario that they have been asked by a senior manager to identify the workforce planning issues for their section over the next two years. The context will be clearly described, including the level and scope of the manager the brief is for. There will be a two page executive overview and then a range of appendices to support the content in the brief. No recommendations are required – only an explanation of why there needs to be a plan, what it could and should address, why it would be an efficacious tactic and what it would be designed to achieve.


Students will be issued with a marking rubric for the reflective portfolio entry at the outset of the course. They will submit their assessment and a self-assessment into Moodle. The assessment will be marked using the rubric and then returned to them with the completed rubric and comments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0990a472db83d850eb6b147a3a961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d190a472db83d850eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ec90a472db83d850eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a2efd432db83d850eb6b147a3a961958","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"35","description":"

Students will pick an element of the organisational system (e.g. talent management; diversity management; organisational capability; flexible work practices; changing skill set etc.) and write an essay which develops an argument as to how workforce planning helps in the effective implementation of such an initiative. The desired outcomes will need to be defined and how the theoretical and practical elements all fit together.

Students will be issued with a marking rubric for the reflective portfolio entry at the outset of the course. They will submit their assessment and a self-assessment into Moodle. The assessment will be marked using the rubric and then returned to them with the completed rubric and comments.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3d90e472db83d850eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"d190a472db83d850eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"ec90a472db83d850eb6b147a3a9619bc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"eaefd432db83d850eb6b147a3a96195d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Implementation Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"45","description":"

Based on the work in Assessment 1 students will prepare a report for the same manager which applies the student’s workforce planning knowledge to the scenario. Content will include a fuller evaluation of the current workforce planning systems, what needs changing and why. 

Students will be issued with a marking rubric for the reflective portfolio entry at the outset of the course. They will submit their assessment and a self-assessment into Moodle. The assessment will be marked using the rubric and then returned to them with the completed rubric and comments.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"0990a472db83d850eb6b147a3a961918","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3d90e472db83d850eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"eeefd432db83d850eb6b147a3a961992","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/ZBUS8317.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This course introduces students to the knowledge, skills and approaches they will need to manage across borders and cultures.  The course provides conceptual and theoretical frameworks for understanding cultural differences, as well as the challenges of cross-cultural communication for the dynamics of multicultural work teams and organisations at home and internationally.

contentlets.keywords: business,cross- cultural management,international organisations,multicultural work groups,cross cultural negotiation and understanding
contentlets.description: This course introduces students to the knowledge, skills and approaches they will need to manage across borders and cultures.  The course provides conceptual and theoretical frameworks for understanding cultural differences, as well as the challenges of cross-cultural communication for the dynamics of multicultural work teams and organisations at home and internationally.
contentlets.title: Cross Cultural Management

This course is designed to provide students with an analytical, theoretical and practical understanding of strategic logistics management practice in medium to large private sector companies and their public sector equivalents. This course builds on knowledge gained in earlier prerequisite units (ZBUS8302 – Logistics Management and ZBUS8313 Risk Management) to bring together previous knowledge to provide for a richer theoretical and relevant practical expertise.


The course uses simulation and role-play to allow students to experiment with different strategies and determine how people and organisations react to collaboration in a supply chain to ensure good outcomes for all participants.  The course has learning opportunities and assessments that enable students to demonstrate their practical and theoretical understanding of supply chain strategy development and implementation in green or brownfield sites.

contentlets.description:
This course is designed to provide students with an analytical, theoretical and practical understanding of strategic logistics management practice in medium to large private sector companies and their public sector equivalents. This course builds on knowledge gained in earlier prerequisite units (ZBUS8302 – Logistics Management and ZBUS8313 Risk Management) to bring together previous knowledge to provide for a richer theoretical and relevant practical expertise.

The course uses simulation and role-play to allow students to experiment with different strategies and determine how people and organisations react to collaboration in a supply chain to ensure good outcomes for all participants.  The course has learning opportunities and assessments that enable students to demonstrate their practical and theoretical understanding of supply chain strategy development and implementation in green or brownfield sites.
contentlets.title: Strategic Logistics Management

This course examines concepts and theories that enhance understanding of equality, diversity, and inclusion and the development of individual, team and organisational knowledge and skills. The unit highlights structural, organisational and individual factors which can impede successful diversity management, and provides students with a range of tools to ensure they can progress effective diversity management in their organisation. Topics will include: theories of difference, equality, diversity and inclusion; the business case for diversity management; the legal frameworks to prevent discrimination; bullying, violence and psycho-social safety at work; barriers experienced by various diversity target groups (including women, First Nation peoples, those from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds, older workers and LGBTQI+ workers); the construction of merit and operation of biases; organisational change; and inclusive leadership. The aim is to enable students to understand the complexities of diversity management so that they can create and maintain an inclusive and diverse workplace, and develop, implement and evaluate successful diversity management policies.

The unit highlights structural, organisational and individual factors which can impede successful diversity management, and provides students with a range of tools to ensure they can progress effective diversity management in their organisation. Topics will include: theories of difference, equality, diversity and inclusion; the business case for diversity management; the legal frameworks to prevent discrimination; bullying, violence and psycho-social safety at work; barriers experienced by various diversity target groups (including women, First Nation peoples, those from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds, older workers and LGBTQI+ workers); the construction of merit and operation of biases; organisational change; and inclusive leadership. The aim is to enable students to understand the complexities of diversity management so that they can create and maintain an inclusive and diverse workplace, and develop, implement and evaluate successful diversity management policies.

contentlets.keywords: business,asset management,asset life cycle,total value of ownership,total cost of ownership,total risk of ownership,capability including readiness and sustainability,asset value including: capability; availability; reliability; maintainability.
contentlets.description: In order to do its job, the Australian Defence Force maintains a large and diverse portfolio of platforms, systems and infrastructure.  The skill and insight with which this portfolio of military assets is managed largely determines how quickly the ADF can respond to government tasking and how long it can perform such tasks. Extracting the most value from such military assets within the assigned budget requires defence asset managers to make many trade-offs over the asset life cycle in a structured and systematic way.  Asset Management aims to equip defence asset managers with the insight, skills and techniques they need to perform this task efficiently and effectively.
contentlets.title: Asset Management

This course seeks to establish robust conceptual foundations for the conduct of projects. The focus of the Course is on the project as a domain of investment decision-making rather than merely as a platform for the exercise of rules and procedures. ZBUS8912 introduces a rigorous theoretical framework from which are drawn a suite of supporting analytical tools. These are then used to explore a number of important contemporary issues in project management across the public, private and social sectors. The course is not methodology-based. (The PMBoK and PRINCE2 are touched on, but only as topics for the short research papers prepared as items of course assessment).

Defence business managers operate in a dynamic environment, with economic and technological changes combining with evolving policy, military and governance requirements. To be effective in this dynamic environment, defence business managers need to be able to articulate the kind of vision required to lead change and promote innovation. The course aims to assist Defence managers to develop the leadership and change management competencies required to influence stakeholders inside and outside of their organisation. To this end the course will explore leadership frameworks and the effect of leadership on organisational performance and the processes involved in managing a change intervention, in particular their capability to lead a Defence sustainment change initiative. In addition, the course examines the importance of innovation and explores how organisational leaders can plan and manage for innovation.
